review.title: The Complexity of Integer Bound Propagation
review.abstract: Bound propagation is an important Artificial Intelligence technique used in Constraint Programming tools to deal with numerical constraints. It is typically embedded within a search procedure ("branch and prune") and used at every node of the search tree to narrow down the search space, so it is critical that it be fast. The procedure invokes constraint propagators until a common fixpoint is reached, but the known algorithms for this have a pseudo-polynomial worst-case time complexity: they are fast indeed when the variables have a small numerical range, but they have the well-known problem of being prohibitively slow when these ranges are large. An important question is therefore whether strongly-polynomial algorithms exist that compute the common bound consistent fixpoint of a set of constraints. This paper answers this question. In particular we show that this fixpoint computation is in fact NP-complete, even when restricted to binary linear constraints.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction and Overview of the Main Results
sections.text: Propagation is an iterative process that propagates any limitation of the problem with each iteration to narrow down the domains of its variables, and the iteration stops if no constraint changes the domains of its variables. In this case, propagation has reached a common fixed point for all constraints; this iterative algorithm guarantees that the fixed point is calculated in polynomial time when the propagation of each constraint takes polynomial time and the domains of the variables are defined as value lists. However, very often it is inconvenient or impossible to explicitly list all values: instead, the domains are defined by lower and upper limits. We focus on this representation and on variables that take integer values. In this setting, the calculation of a fixed point by the iterative algorithm requires exponential time.

sections.heading: 1.2 Prior Complexity Results on Propagation
sections.text: Standard propagation algorithms are iterative processes that employ "propagators," i.e., narrow down the functions associated with each restriction until they reach a fixed point. Therefore, their complexity is determined by two complementary questions: Q1: How difficult is it to calculate each propagator? Q2: How difficult is it to find a common fixed point of propagators? The complexity of the propagation of constraints has been studied extremely well in a certain sense, but all the results we know for bound propagation deal only with question 1. These earlier hardness results showed that for some complex constraints we cannot have polynomial time propagators that achieve a certain degree of consistency. Two such results are: • Given a linear equality, it has been observed that the propagation of Yuanlin & Yap, 2000; Choi, Harvey, Lee, & Stuckey, 2006) is that any propagator that achieves consistency or Z bound.

sections.heading: 1.3 Our Main Results
sections.text: In this paper, we look at very simple common propagators and address question 2. We show that even surprisingly simple propagators in general can lead to a fixed point calculation problem that is NP-hard. This not only explains why all standard, iterative fixed point calculation algorithms in practice have an exponential worst case, but also shows that there is unlikely to be a better worst case algorithm. In particular, an important class of simple propagators whose fixed point calculation is NP-hard is the bound (R) consistency propagator for linear constraints (Proposition 1). These are ubiquitous constraints and very weak and widespread propagators for these constraints. Many problems that use numerical calculations and large domains tend to include at least linear constraints, so there are few cases where slow convergence is avoidable.

sections.heading: 2. Formal Background
sections.text: In this section we summarize the necessary material for Constraint Satisfaction Problems and bound propagation. Further details on this material can be found in essays by e.g. Schulte and Carlsson (2006) and Bessie Horre (2006).

sections.heading: 2.1 Constraint Satisfaction Problems
sections.text: A constraint satisfaction problem (CSP) is a triple < X, D, C >, where: X = {x1 · · xn} is a set of variables, D = {D1 · · · Dn} is a set of finite domains (finite sets of values), one for each variable, and C is a set of constraints. In this essay, we will consider discrete domains: All elements in D are integers. At the moment, we generally define constraints as logical predicates of subsets of X; later in the essay, we will consider specific types of constraints, for example linear. An assignment is a function that assigns a value equilibrium (xi) to each variable xi.

sections.heading: 4. Generalizations and Non-Linear Constraints
sections.text: With Sentence 1, the fixed point calculation is insoluble for such basic and everyday numerical constraints as linear constraints. Nevertheless, several cases of nonlinear constraints are of interest. First, we show that if we add the simplest possible type of polynomial (a single square operation) to linear constraints, our overall hardness result can be strengthened. Second, it is interesting to note that when we add simple minimum or maximum constraints to linear constraints, the fixed point calculation corresponds to a puzzling open problem recently discussed in the theoretical literature. Finally, we briefly comment on the links between our results and the traceability of max-closed constraints.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: Thinking about intervals was introduced into the AI literature by the work of Cleary (1987) and Davis (1987) 5. A considerable amount of AI work has resulted from this (see e.g. Hyvos, 1992); bound calculation is used by most finite CP solvers today (Schulte & Carlsson, 2006).In this paper, we have theoretically investigated the complexity of calculating the common fixed point of a set of bound consistency propagators. We have also shown that even if the propagators themselves are very simple, the fixed point calculation used in these algorithms can be complex, it is actually NP-complete, even for a very limited constraint class - linear monotonous inequalities with two variables per inequality. We have also looked at some special classes of constraints, such as square constraints and maximum constraints of Bosie.

A particularly relevant algorithm for TVPI constraints is proposed in the work of BarYehuda and Rawitz (2001). This algorithm has pseudo-polynomial time complexity with low, strongly polynomial space requirements.

We can now prove our NP-hardness result from monotone TVPI constraints, using the following result: Theorem 1 (Lagarias, 1985) The feasibility of Two-Variable-Per-Inequality monotone Integer Programming is NP-complete.
Note that we have been careful in the statement of Observation 2: whether Linear Programming is strongly polynomial is in fact a longstanding open question (Smale, 1998).

The best “polynomial-time” LP algorithms are, encouragingly, of time complexity O(π(n,m, b)) for some polynomial π, where b is the number of bits of the number encoding—this looks strongly polynomial (Khachian, 1979).
This is perhaps the most important class of linear constraints whose integer feasibility can be solved in strongly polynomial time, see for instance work by Jaffar et al. (1994).

With respect to restrictions on the constraint graph, there are nevertheless reasons to be pessimistic: we note that the feasibility of monotone TVPI Integer Programming remains NP-complete under strict restrictions on the constraint graph, as shown in the work of Hochbaum and Naor (1994). This suggests that such restrictions are unlikely to lead to interesting tractable classes of fixpoint computation.

In fact, a recent result (Atserias & Maneva, 2010) shows that the complexity of Max-Atom is equivalent to well-known open problems called mean-payoff games, which have in turn connections to some important open questions in model-checking: parity games, a class of games reducible to mean-payoff games, are equivalent to the model-checking problem of μ-calculus (Emerson, Jutla, & Sistla, 1993; Jurdzinski, 1998).

The work reported by Bezem et al. (2008) shows a number of results on the feasibility of conjunctions of max-atom constraints: (1) There is no significant complexity difference between integer and real feasibility; (2) The problem can be decided in pseudo-polynomial time using what amounts to a fixpoint computation algorithm; (3) The problem has short proofs of unsatisfiability and is therefore in NP∩coNP; which means that it is of a very different nature from our other NP-complete variants.

3 Max-Closed Constraints We last note a connection between our results and the class of max-closed constraints introduced by Jeavons and Cooper (1995) (more on this in, e.g., Petke & Jeavons, 2009). A constraint R(x1, . . . , xn) is max-closed if whenever we have two solutions 〈v1 . . . vn〉 and 〈w1 . . . wn〉, their maximum defined as 〈max(v1, w1), . . . ,max(vn, wn)〉 is also a solution. Results by Jeavons and Cooper (1995) show that max-closed constraints are tractable: if a system of constraints is max-closed, then its feasibility can be determined in polynomial time.

In sharp contrast to the case of explicitly-defined constraints, the resolution of implicitly-defined max-closed constraints is therefore only pseudopolynomial and it is in fact intractable, as shown by the special case of monotone TVPI constraints: Observation 3 The feasibility of ”implicitly-defined” max-closed constraints is NP-complete.

There is a large literature on propagating single constraints (Van Hoeve & Katriel, 2006; Bessière, 2006; Rossi, van Beek, & Walsh, 2006) and it is perhaps a surprise that no prior study exists on the complexity of the fixpoint computation.

metadata.abstractText: Bound propagation is an important Artificial Intelligence technique used in Constraint Programming tools to deal with numerical constraints. It is typically embedded within a search procedure (”branch and prune”) and used at every node of the search tree to narrow down the search space, so it is critical that it be fast. The procedure invokes constraint propagators until a common fixpoint is reached, but the known algorithms for this have a pseudo-polynomial worst-case time complexity: they are fast indeed when the variables have a small numerical range, but they have the well-known problem of being prohibitively slow when these ranges are large. An important question is therefore whether stronglypolynomial algorithms exist that compute the common bound consistent fixpoint of a set of constraints. This paper answers this question. In particular we show that this fixpoint computation is in fact NP-complete, even when restricted to binary linear constraints.
